Detailed Description

Client interface and base class for directory iterators.

Abstract class DirectoryIterator defines the interface for directory iterators. A directory iterator is initialized with a directory pathname and iterates over files and directories in this directory. The files to be iterated can be filtered. Subdirectories are not recursively iterated, this has to be programmed by the client explicitly.

Since a virtual root storage device which unifies all storage devices that are actually registered to the root file system is available (device Id rfs), it is rather easy to write code for iterating any directory on any storage device. A function which takes the path of a directory to be iterated and a string to write the contents of this directory to could actually look like this:

    static BOOLEAN IterateDirectory(Pathname dir_pathname, WString &dir_content)
    {
        // Get the directory iterator from the root file system.
        DirectoryIteratorPtr itor = RootFileSystem::GetDirectoryIterator(
            dir_pathname,       // The directory to iterate.
            FileFilterPtr(0),   // Empty filter, we get all files.
            L"rfs");            // Storage device Id of the virtual root device.

        if (!itor.IsValid()) {
            DBG_OUT((0, L"A directory iterator could not be created.\n"));
            return FALSE;
        }

        // Iterate all entries in the directory and write the pathnames of the
        // entries to string dir_content.
        for ( ; itor->IsValid(); itor->Increment()) {
            const Pathname &actual_pathname = itor->GetPathname();
            dir_content << actual_pathname.ToWString() << L"\n";
        }

        return TRUE;
    }

If you pass for example path /ffs as parameter dir_pathname to the function above then the contents of the flash file system gets written to dir_content since the virtual root storage device holds all the storage devices currently registered to the system as entries of its first-level directory. Hence, to get a list of all the registered storage devices you can pass the root directory / to the function.

Nevertheless you might prefer to work with a dedicated storage device directly. One reason for this might be the fact that it is slightly faster because of implementation issues. Of course this is also possible. E.g., for iterating all files stored on the flash file system, see the following sample function:

    static BOOLEAN IterateFlashStorageDevice()
    {
        // Get the directory iterator from the root file system.
        DirectoryIteratorPtr itor = RootFileSystem::GetDirectoryIterator(
            Pathname(),         // Constructs the root pathname "/".
            FileFilterPtr(0),   // Empty filter, we get all files.
            L"ffs");            // Storage device Id string of the flash device.

        if (!itor.IsValid()) {
            DBG_OUT((0, L"A directory iterator could not be created.\n"));
            return FALSE;
        }

        for ( ; itor->IsValid(); itor->Increment()) {
            const Pathname &actual_pathname = itor->GetPathname();

            // Work with the pathname...
        }

        return TRUE;
    }

Caveat: if the file that a valid iterator points to is deleted then the iterator gets invalid! Using it further on results in undefined behavior and is not allowed. This has to be assured by the client logic.

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

DirectoryIterator::~DirectoryIterator (   )  [virtual]
 

Destroys the directory iterator.

DirectoryIterator::DirectoryIterator (  const Pathname &  dir_pathname,
const FileFilterPtr &  filter,
const WString &  device_Id
)  [explicit, protected]
 

Constructs a directory iterator for directory dir_pathname on storage device with storage device Id device_Id. The iterator retrieves files and directories whose names comply with filter. This is the only constructor since a non-initialized directory iterator is not allowed. Subclasses have to provide a constructor with the same formal arguments and must initialize m_cur_path to either

  • the pathname of the first file or directory in directory dir_pathname or to
  • the root pathname signaling the end iterator.

Parameters:
dir_pathname The pathname of the directory whose files and subdirectories are to be iterated.
filter A file filter functor.
device_Id The Id of the storage device.

Member Function Documentation

void DirectoryIterator::ApplyInitialFilter (   )  [protected]
 

This method has to be called at the end of the constructor of any derived class. Precondition is that m_cur_path is either the

  • pathname of the first file or directory in directory dir_pathname or
  • the root pathname signaling the end iterator. It checks if m_cur_path complies to the given filter criterion and if not, iterates to the first file or directory complying to it.

virtual DirectoryIterator& DirectoryIterator::AtomicIncrement (   )  [protected, pure virtual]
 

Increments the iterator to point to the next pathname in the directory and returns a reference to itself. This increment operation does not consider the filter set on construction. Only valid iterators are allowed to be incremented. If this method gets called on the end iterator an assertion holds.

Returns:
Reference to itself incremented to point to the next pathname or to the root pathname signaling the end iterator.

Implemented in FatDirectoryIteratorImp, FlashDirectoryIteratorImp, RamDirectoryIteratorImp, and RootDirectoryIteratorImp.

File::Error DirectoryIterator::GetLastError (   )  const [virtual]
 

Returns the error occurred by the last operation.

Reimplemented in RootDirectoryIteratorImp.

const Path & DirectoryIterator::GetPath (   )  const [virtual]
 

Returns the path of the file or directory the iterator currently points to. Only valid iterators are allowed to be accessed. If the iterator is the end iterator, i.e. the current pathname is the root pathname, then an assertion holds.

const Pathname & DirectoryIterator::GetPathname (   )  const [virtual]
 

Returns the pathname of the file or directory the iterator currently points to. Only valid iterators are allowed to be accessed. If the iterator is the end iterator, i.e. the current pathname is the root pathname, then an assertion holds.

void DirectoryIterator::Increment (   )  [virtual]
 

Increments the iterator to refer to the next pathname or to the root pathname if the iterator gets invalid. This increment operation considers the filter set on construction. Only valid iterators are allowed to be incremented. If this method gets called on the end iterator an assertion holds.

Reimplemented in RootDirectoryIteratorImp.

BOOLEAN DirectoryIterator::IsValid (   )  const
 

Tells if the iterator points to some file or directory. This is determined by simply checking the current pathname. If the current pathname is the root pathname it is not valid, otherwise it is valid. Note that if the file that the iterator points to is deleted the iterator gets invalid and must not be used anymore. This has to be assured by the client logic, otherwise undefined behavior is the consequence.

Returns:
Returns if the iterator is valid.

Field Documentation

Path DirectoryIterator::m_cur_path [protected]
 

The pathname the iterator currently points to. The root pathname signals the end iterator.

const Pathname DirectoryIterator::m_dir_pathname [protected]
 

The directory pathname this iterator was opened for.

The filter functor to apply.
